sub_topic: Using the mean value theorem to solve problems
message_1: A car travels from point A to point B in 4 hours. The distance between A and B is 320 km. Using the mean value theorem, find the average velocity of the car on this trip.
message_2:
The Mean Value Theorem states that if a function is continuous on a closed interval [a, b] and differentiable on the open interval (a, b), then there exists a point c in the interval (a, b) such that the derivative of the function at c is equal to the average rate of change of the function over the interval [a, b].

In this problem, we are given the distance traveled (320 km) and the time taken (4 hours) to travel between points A and B. We need to find the average velocity of the car on this trip.

The average velocity can be calculated as the total distance traveled divided by the total time taken. In this case, the average velocity (v_avg) can be calculated as:

v_avg = (Total distance) / (Total time)
v_avg = 320 km / 4 hours
v_avg = 80 km/h

So, the average velocity of the car on this trip is 80 km/h.
